channel.title: IF Answers - Recent questions and answers in Publishing

item.title: Answered: How do I delete a game from the whole website?
item.description: Fill in the contact form on the website, and include a link to the game, and I'll delete it for you.

item.title: Selling games?
item.description: Basically, it says you can sell the games you make. So can the windows version export EXE's or something? Thanks!

item.title: Answered: No option to save a .quest file?
item.description:
This looks like a bug in Quest where the window isn't displaying fully when you're using high DPI settings.

As a workaround, go into your display preferences and set display scaling to 100%. You should then be able to see the Publish button on that window.

Alternatively, just hitting the Enter key when that window is open might work.

item.title: Answered: How to make pictures show up when playing online.
item.description:
Parchment doesn't support graphics.

I would try Quixe instead--see ยง25.11. A playable web page in the manual to "release along with an interpreter." You can try it on your own computer to see if it displays the pictures (the game doesn't have to be online--you can open it offline in a browser) and then if the pictures work, you could ask the comp organizer whether it's possible to set up Quixe instead of Parchment for online play of your game.

There's a sample game here http://eblong.com/zarf/glulx/quixe/ called "Sensory Jam" that shows graphics in Quixe, so it seems like it ought to be possible to display pictures. But the version of Quixe that comes with Inform isn't the latest, I don't think, so if that one doesn't support graphics you could try a more recent version of Quixe.

item.title: Can I supply my own CSS to the gs.tads.io server / interpreter?
item.description:
Now that I know that I can straight up send the gs.tads.io server my games, can I change the output in any way, or am I stuck with it's fonts, colors, etc.?

Thanks!

item.title: Answered: Does Squiffy use the same MIT licence as Quest?
item.description:
Here's the license: https://github.com/textadventures/squiffy/blob/master/LICENSE

You can usually find the license with the source code, in a file named LICENSE

item.title: Answered: Can I share an unfinished game?
item.description: Yes, when you go to publish the game, there is an option to leave the game unisted so that only those with the link can play.

item.title: Answered: Is there a Javascript Interpreter for TADS that I can run on my website?
item.description:
There aren't Javascript interpreters for TADS in the same way as there are for Inform games. You can play TADS 3 games in a browser, but they run on a server, so setting it up is a bit more complicated than just uploading some files to your website.

To begin with, you'll need to compile your TADS 3 game with the WebUI version of the library you're using. If you've already started writing the game with the standard UI version of the library, that's fine. The easiest way to switch is to start a new project using the WebUI version of the library, and then add your existing source code files to the new project. If you want to, you can then compile from both of the projects to get both a web version and a download version of the game. If you want to see how this works, you can look at the source code of my game It (http://ifdb.tads.org/viewgame?id=clox1mlffo37xf2z) which includes both standard UI and WebUI project files.

To use the IFDB online play feature, you just need to create an IFDB page for your game. In the Downloads section of the page, add a link to the WebUI version of your game, wherever it happens to be online (e.g. the IF Archive, your website) and select "TADS 3 Web" as the File Type. IFDB will automatically generate a Play Online button for the game. You can then link from your website to the IFDB Play Online page for your game.

One problem with this is that the link will go through IFDB first and invite players to log in before playing, so they can save their progress on the IFDB server. You don't have to log in to play the game, but it's still not very friendly to casual players. Plus, you may not want to create an IFDB page immediately, for instance if you just want to share the game with a few beta testers at first.

If you'd rather provide a way that people can jump straight into your game, you can use the gs.tads.io server instead of the IFDB. You just create a link to http://gs.tads.io/?storyfile=[url_of_your_game]. For instance, you can play It at http://gs.tads.io/?storyfile=http://boeghe.im/dl/it_web2.2.t3.

item.title: Answered: Upload a game from Inklewriter
item.description: From the inklewriter editor, click the "share" link at the top. Then click the Release button on the window that pops up. This will take you through the submission process at textadventures.co.uk.

item.title: Ascii Art, Images and Music when publishing
item.description:
I assume the main places for publishing IF are through the text adventures site, through ifdb (often played through frotz) or as a separate website or app(converting html to an app).

I was wondering about using images, ascii art and music across different publishing platforms.

Does Frotz for iphone, iPad and Android support audio? I haven't played any IF that has used sound , images or ascii art using Frotz but I was unsure?

I am considering building a text adenture that uses lots of glitchy electronic music in different sections but wanted to find out if it would translate across different platforms.

Has anyone tried making a quest game (with music or images), changing the html to an app through 'Phonegap'. Have you had any success with this? I was just keen to explore this and wondered if anyone had tried it so I could learn from any mistakes or limitations.

item.title: Answered: Which textadventures.co.uk category would best fit a stock market-like game?
item.description:
I was contemplating jokes about why a stock market game could be considered "fantasy" or even "comedy" (or perhaps "mystery"), but that wouldn't be helpful for you. :)

I've had a similar problem to this with writing, where a story might not fit so neatly into a genre, or it straddles multiple ones. Rather than suggest a category for you (since it's really arbitrary and ultimately up to you), I'll offer a strategy:

Rather than look at your game and see which categories it fits (which could be many), I'd look at the categories and see where you'd like your game to be, both in terms of any connotations you might have about the category and what kind of audience might choose that category.

In other words, choose the category that allows your desired audience to find it most easily. If you were looking for your game (or a game like yours), where would you look for it first?

Just my take.

item.title: Answered: QuestJS asked for a .quest file and when I save my Quest adventure it saves as a .aslx file
item.description:
Well to answer that question Aslx was just the source code, It was so simple I tested it in the editor and didn't compile it
Paul

item.title: Answered: Can you use custom CSS files with games uploaded to textadvenures.co.uk?
item.description:
It should work, as long as everything's in the ZIP file you uploaded.

Make sure your CSS is using relative and not absolute paths - because uploaded games have URLs of the form media.textadventures.co.uk/gameid/..., so if you're linking to something like /mystyle.css then that won't work.

If you add a link to your game here I can look into it further.

item.title: Answered: How should you attribute an extensions you've made a small change to?
item.description:
As an author I would not want anything attributed to me that I haven't actually made. That includes minor direct edits. So in fact to me it is quite more fair to be credited as the original author of a modified extension even when the modification is superficial.

There are also other benefits to creating new versions of modified extensions: otherwise if you update the original or accidentally re-install it, you'll lose any custom modifications. Keeping the unmodified version around will also give you an easily accessible reference point when you forget what exactly it was that you changed. You'll also have the original version for use in other projects that don't need modifications.

item.title: Answered: Can I edit a game that I have already published?
item.description: Yes, just makes your edits and then publish it again.

item.title: Answered: How do I delete a game?
item.description:
Are you are asking how to delete an Inform project from your computer? If so...

Go to the folder where your Inform projects get saved (if you're not sure what folder that is, check to see what folder opens when you start Inform and click "open an existing project").

Inside this folder there should be two folders associated with each project--one folder ending in .inform and one folder ending in .materials, but they'll both have the same filename otherwise--and you can delete those the way you'd delete any other folder, by dragging them to the recycle bin or what have you.

item.title: Answered: Stupid Reviews on My Game!
item.description:
PM Alex (quest creator) about it (he can fix~remove the bad review ~ not sure if the other mods of quest site have this power or not), as quest community and staff, is still brainstorming possibly better systems, to try to deal with the universal issues of review systems, as seen here:

http://forum.textadventures.co.uk/viewtopic.php?f=5&t=4061

this is a common issue for many people creating games with quest and all the other engines too (or any type of review, as it's not just limited to games, laughs).

item.title: Answered: Why is my game still "unlisted" on textadventures.co.uk?
item.description:
To make a game public, you need to choose a category as well, so make sure you're doing that.

Once you've made a game public, it doesn't go into its category immediately. First, a moderator must check it. Games which are not of sufficient quality to qualify for their category will be placed in the Sandpit instead.
